conclusion: Understanding what a velocity-time graph tells me.
In a velocity-time graph, x-axis is time and y-axis is velocity.
Time goes from 0 to 3 seconds, velocity ranges from -2 m/s to +2 m/s.
From t=0 to t=1 second, velocity is constant at +2 m/s.
At t=1 second, velocity starts to decrease linearly.
At t=2 seconds, velocity crosses zero and becomes negative.
At t=3 seconds, velocity reaches -2 m/s.
From t=0 to t=1 second, motion is positive, constant velocity.
From t=1 to t=2 seconds, velocity decreases from +2 m/s to 0 m/s.
From t=2 to t=3 seconds, velocity is negative, meaning motion is in the negative direction.
Since positive direction is upwards, negative velocity means motion is opposite to positive direction.
From t=2 to t=3 seconds, particle is moving in the negative direction, opposite to positive direction.
At t=2 seconds, velocity is 0 m/s.
At t=3 seconds, velocity is -2 m/s.
Between t=2 and t=3 seconds, particle is moving with negative velocity, hence in negative direction.
Motion direction from t=2 to t=3 seconds is opposite to the defined positive direction.
Consider acceleration to be sure.
From t=0 to t=1 second, velocity is constant, so acceleration is 0.
From t=1 to t=3 seconds, velocity decreases linearly from +2 m/s to -2 m/s.
Slope of v-t graph gives acceleration: -2 m/sÂ² from t=1 to t=3 seconds.
For direction of motion, sign of velocity matters, not acceleration.
From t=2 to t=3 seconds, velocity is negative, meaning motion is in the negative direction, opposite to positive direction.
